results.title: Sir Francis Drake
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and John Barnes
results.brief_description: Dramatises the preparation and execution of Sir Francis Drake’s raids on the Pacific coast empire of Spain in America. Illuminates the conflicting parties at Elizabeth I’s court - those wishing to conciliate the mighty Philip II, of Spain, and those who sought to attack his vast empire, seize gold and gain glory. Shows how Drake’s extended raid in the Pacific led to the circumnavigation of the world by his ship, the Golden Hind.

results.title: Sir Alec Guinness Ealing comedy: Kind hearts and coronets; The Man in the white suit; The Lavender Hill mob; The Ladykillers
results.creator_credit: Ealing Studios, Robert Hamer, Charles Crichton and Alexander Mackendrick
results.brief_description: Four features starring Sir Alec Guinness produced by the revered Ealing studio. In “The Ladykillers” Guinness guides a gang of misfits through a daring robbery only to be foiled by their seemingly harmless, elderly landlady. Set in Edwardian England, “Kind hearts and coronets” sees Guinness play eight parts - all victims of a serial killer, determined to claim his birthright. A satire on industry and commerce “The Man in the white suit” features Guinness as a would-be chemist who develops an indestructible fabric. Guinness plays a timid bank clerk who has the perfect scheme for stealing gold bullion from the Bank of England in “The Lavender Hill mob”. These four comedies highlight Guinness’ unerring talent for satire and farce. Also available on VHS “The Lavender Hill Mob” [302796], “Kind Hearts and coronets” [302542], “The Ladykillers” [304307], “The Man in the white suit” [507924].

results.title: Sins of the father and of the son
results.creator_credit: National Film School (Great Britain), Jackie Johnstone and Harry Hook
results.brief_description: Starring Jonathan Dockar-Drysdale, Hilary Hook, Camille Davies, Gigi Soames. Tells of a young man’s journey to see his estranged father, a retired Army Colonel living on an island in the Indian Ocean where he studies Islamic culture. The strangeness of the culture and the surroundings lead to a break in the father and son’s relationship.

results.title: Single sculling techniques
results.creator_credit: Dan Productions, Elizabeth Isaacs and Michael Johns
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sports training film series”.
Slow motion and freeze-frame photography is used to demonstrate common faults in sculling techniques, and showing the correct techniques. Excellent film with very good commentary.

results.title: Single file
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Gil Brealey and Robert Kingsbury
results.brief_description: Illustrates the problems concerned when a file is misplaced in an office situation - intended as training for public service employees, but is applicable in any office. Shows the worry and concern caused by inefficient methods of work, clutter, lack of interest and poor organisation in loaning, distributing and return of files.

results.title: Singing Stone
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
A hand clutches an oval stone which is drawn back and forth in tight circular motions, grinding pigment. Produced with a black and white half inch reel-to-reel portapak video recorder (manufactured c1975). ‘Singing Stone’ demonstrates Callas’ early experimentation with colouriser painting techniques. The effect is one of visual distortion in which pictorial surface and depth oscillate, creating a sense of dislocation and hallucination.
Notes by Rachel Kent, reprinted courtesy of the author and d/Lux Media Arts.

results.title: Singin' in the rain [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Arthur Freed, Gene Kelly and Stanley Donen
results.brief_description: The seemingly eternal freshness of “Singin’ in the rain” may be the result of an unusual degree of improvisation involved in its making. More than most musicals this was a team effort - a coming together of talents striving to overcome the limitations that they saw in the material and given space in which to move. In the process they not only produced one of the finest of movie musicals but also one of the best Hollywood-on-Hollywood movies - an intelligent and affectionate satire on the coming of synchronised sound. It is also a high point of what Richard Dyer calls the Utopian musical of the fifties which erased the distinction between the narrative and the musical numbers, the ultimate management of the contradiction between realism and fantasy inherent in the genre. Features catchy tunes, lively choreography with the athletic grace and Irish charm of Gene Kelly, engaging performances and hilarious jokes. Gene Kelly was co-director, choreographer and actor in this spectacular musical and in 1989 it was one of the first twenty-five films selected by the US Library of Congress for its National Film Registry of significant films.
